summary:
• Australia's new 'men's behavior change' secretary acknowledges that the role will be challenging.
• The secretary recognizes that addressing men's behavior requires a deep understanding of societal norms and values.
• The position aims to promote positive social change through targeted interventions.

• A Canadian paleontologist discovers a significant dinosaur fossil in Alberta, estimated to be worth over $1 million.
• The fossil is expected to provide valuable insights into prehistoric life during the Late Cretaceous period.
• Further research will help scientists learn more about this ancient species and its habitat.

• A viral social media post has garnered over 47 million shares.
• It focuses attention on the situation in Rafah, Egypt.
• No further details about the post or its content are provided.

• A model sues over Cannes red carpet 'assault'.
• Russia not invited to D-Day 80th anniversary ceremonies.
• The Élysée Palace announces that Russia has been excluded from the celebrations marking the 80th anniversary of D-Day in France.

• Hong Kong convicts 14 activists of subversion.
• Convictions involve 14 pro-democracy activists.
• Landmark case.

• South Korea's government is offering financial incentives to encourage men who have had vasectomies to reverse the procedure due to a declining birth rate.
• An Icelandic volcano has erupted, producing intense lava flows in what may be its most powerful eruption yet.

• Israel has extended its control over Gaza's entire land border.
• Most Israelis believe the military's campaign in Gaza was "about right" or insufficient.
• The US-made F16I Sufa fighter jets were reportedly involved in a deadly strike in Rafah.

• Italian Prime Minister states that fascism is "consigned to history".
• Many disagree with this assessment.
• There remains uncertainty about the current state of fascism in Italy.

• Thousands of people rallied in New Zealand to show their support for Māori rights.
• The event aimed to raise awareness about ongoing issues faced by the indigenous Māori community.
• Participants called for greater recognition and protection of Māori cultural heritage and interests.

• North Korea launched waste-filled balloons towards South Korea as a form of provocation.
• The move is seen as a deliberate attempt to stir up tensions between the two nations.
• The balloons carried propaganda materials and other items aimed at ridiculing the South Korean government.

• The Prime Minister of Slovakia has been hospitalized due to health issues
• He was shot during an incident outside his office in Bratislava
• He is being treated at a hospital in the capital city

• Partial results indicate that the African National Congress (ANC) may lose its majority.
• This suggests a significant electoral setback for the ruling party.
• The outcome could have far-reaching implications for South African politics.

• Spain's government has approved an amnesty law that grants pardons to those involved in Catalonia's independence movement
• The law aims to ease tensions between Madrid and Barcelona by forgiving individuals who have been detained or prosecuted for their roles in the push for secession
• The move is seen as a step towards reconciliation and healing after years of political turmoil in Catalonia

• Ukraine allowed to strike certain Russian targets using US-supplied weapons.
• The country is facing its most severe crisis since the beginning of the conflict.
• US President Biden has authorized Ukraine to conduct limited strikes within Russia.

• A tycoon was ordered to pay $1 billion in a record-breaking divorce settlement.
• The UK Parliament has dissolved ahead of a general election.

• Donald Trump found guilty on all counts in historic criminal trial
• Trump says verdict is "a disgrace" and claims it will impact his ability to run for President again; sentencing set for July 11th
• The earliest and most distant galaxy ever observed has been identified by astronomers
